verses.text: For every high priest chosen from among men is appointed on behalf of people in matters relating to God, to offer both gifts and sacrifices for sins.
verses.comment: The high priest serves as a mediator between God and man, prefiguring the ultimate high priesthood of Christ. The concept of offering sacrifices for sins is rooted in Old Testament practices (see Leviticus 16).

verses.text: He is able to deal gently with those who are ignorant and going astray, since he himself is also subject to weakness.
verses.comment: Human priests are compassionate because they share in human frailty. Christ's identification with human weakness is a theme developed throughout Hebrews (see Hebrews 2:18).

verses.text: Because of this, he must offer sacrifices for his own sins as well as for the sins of the people.
verses.comment: Unlike Christ, earthly priests must atone for their own sins. This highlights Christ's unique sinlessness and His superior priesthood (see Hebrews 7:27).

verses.text: And no one takes this honor upon himself; instead, he is called by God, just as Aaron was.
verses.comment: The priestly office is established by God's direct call, emphasizing apostolic succession and authority in church leadership (see Exodus 28:1).

verses.text: In the same way, Christ did not exalt Himself to become high priest, but was appointed by Him who said to Him, 'You are My Son, today I have begotten You.'
verses.comment: Christ receives His priesthood by divine appointment, fulfilling Old Testament prophecy (Psalm 2:7). The divine declaration affirms Christ's unique sonship and authority.

verses.text: As He also says in another place, 'You are a priest forever, according to the order of Melchizedek.'
verses.comment: The order of Melchizedek represents an eternal and royal-priestly office (see Psalm 110:4), foreshadowing a perpetual priestly ministry in Christ.

verses.text: In the days of His flesh, Jesus offered prayers and petitions with loud cries and tears to Him who was able to save Him from death, and He was heard because of His reverent submission.
verses.comment: This verse points to Jesus' prayer at Gethsemane, revealing His true humanity and deep submission to the Father's will. Christ’s prayers show His solidarity with human suffering.

verses.text: Though He was a Son, He learned obedience through what He suffered.
verses.comment: Jesus, in His humanity, matured through suffering, modeling perfect obedience for believers (Philippians 2:8). This underscores the value of suffering in spiritual growth and sanctification.

verses.text: And having been made perfect, He became the source of eternal salvation for all who obey Him.
verses.comment: Christ's perfection through suffering establishes Him as the exclusive source of salvation, given to those who obey (see Hebrews 2:10). Obedience is closely linked to saving faith.

verses.text: Having been declared by God a high priest according to the order of Melchizedek.
verses.comment: Again, the writer emphasizes God's direct appointment of Jesus to an everlasting priesthood, distinct from the Levitical line (Psalm 110:4).

verses.text: About this we have much to say, and it is hard to explain, since you have become dull in your hearing.
verses.comment: The author shifts to a pastoral warning, suggesting the audience’s spiritual immaturity is an obstacle to deeper theological understanding.

verses.text: For though by this time you ought to be teachers, you need someone to teach you again the basic principles of the oracles of God. You need milk, not solid food.
verses.comment: Basic Christian teachings are compared to milk, reserved for spiritual infants, whereas mature teaching is solid food. The theme of progressing beyond elementary doctrines is seen here.

verses.text: For everyone who lives on milk is inexperienced with the word of righteousness, for he is a child.
verses.comment: The 'word of righteousness' points to deeper, life-transforming doctrine and a call to spiritual maturity—beyond a basic understanding of the faith.

verses.text: But solid food is for the mature, for those whose senses have been trained by practice to distinguish good and evil.
verses.comment: Spiritual maturity involves constant practice and moral discernment. The church’s sacramental and doctrinal life is intended to nurture believers toward this maturity and unity.
